definitions.definition: more than is necessary, reasonable or acceptable
definitions.sensetop: excess of somethingto excessin excess of something

examples.text: You can throw away any excess.
Are you suffering from an excess of stress in your life?
In an excess of enthusiasm I agreed to work late.
He was now eating to excess as a result of stress.
The increase will not be in excess of *(= more than)* two per cent.
‘Avoid excess’ is the golden rule for a healthy life.
His statements cannot be simply dismissed as rhetorical excess.
The car can travel at speeds in excess of 150 miles per hour.
The drug can be harmful if taken in excess.

definitions.definition: an amount by which something is larger than something else

examples.text: We cover costs up to £600 and then you pay the excess.

definitions.definition: the part of an insurance claim that a person has to pay while the insurance company pays the rest

examples.text: There is an excess of £100 on each claim under this policy.
Increasing the excess on home insurance from the standard £50 to £100 is likely to save 15%.

definitions.definition: the fact of doing too much of something, especially eating or drinking

examples.text: He gave in to bouts of alcoholic excess.

definitions.definition: extreme behaviour that is unacceptable, illegal or morally wrong

examples.text: We need a free press to curb government excesses.
legislation to control the worst excesses of the press
Washington has always been a city of wretched excesses.
the worst excesses committed by the occupying army

wordOrigin: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin excessus, from excedere ‘go out, surpass’, from ex- ‘out’ + cedere ‘go’.
